details.reused_text: BEIJING (AP) ï¿½ A rash of COVID-19 cases in schools and businesses were reported Friday in areas across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules as it tries to reverse a deepening economic slump.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.
Xiï¿½s government began to loosen controls Nov. 11 after promising to reduce their cost and disruption.
While official data showed a fall in new cases, they no longer cover large parts of the population after the government on Wednesday ended mandatory testing for many people.
On Friday, the government reported 16,797 new cases, including 13,160 without symptoms.
That was down about one-fifth from the previous day and less than half of last weekï¿½s daily peak above 40,000.
While official data showed a fall in new cases, they no longer cover large parts of the population after the government on Wednesday ended mandatory testing for many people.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.
While official data showed a fall in new cases, they no longer cover large parts of the population after the government on Wednesday ended mandatory testing for many people.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.

Nobodyï¿½s used to this yet.ï¿½

In other cities, social media users said coworkers or classmates were ill and some businesses had closed due to a lack of staff.
But those donï¿½t include an unknown number of people who stay at home with COVID-19 symptoms and never report to the government.
ï¿½Thereï¿½s very few people coming in because thereï¿½s so many cases,ï¿½ said Gang Xueping, a waitress in a Beijing restaurant.
ï¿½The countryï¿½s just opened up.
The first one or two months is definitely going to be serious.
ï¿½Thereï¿½s very few people coming in because thereï¿½s so many cases,ï¿½ said Gang Xueping, a waitress in a Beijing restaurant.
The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other countries that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.

The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other countries that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

(AP Photo/Ng Han Guan)

A surge of Covid-19 cases in schools and businesses has been reported by social media users across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules in a bid to reverse a deepening economic slump.

ï¿½Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks,ï¿½ said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, ï¿½but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

Elderly residents wear masks as they visit a hospital in Beijing (AP)

A rash of Covid-19 cases in schools and businesses were reported by social media users Friday in areas across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules

A rash of COVID-19 cases in schools and businesses were reported by social media users Friday in areas across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules as it tries to reverse a deepening economic slump.
But they are a jarring change for China, where zero COVID, which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks, said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from zero-COVID restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where zero COVID, which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.
This week's changes follow protests that erupted November 25 in Shanghai, Beijing and other cities against the human cost of zero COVID.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from zero-COVID restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where zero COVID, which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.
This week's changes follow protests that erupted November 25 in Shanghai, Beijing and other cities against the human cost of zero COVID.
Xi's government began to loosen controls on November 11 after promising to reduce their cost and disruption.
On Friday, the government reported 16,797 new cases, including 13,160 without symptoms.
That was down about one-fifth from the previous day and less than half of last week's daily peak above 40,000.
It wasn't clear from those accounts, many of which couldn't be independently confirmed, how far above the official figure the total case numbers might be.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.
It wasn't clear from those accounts, many of which couldn't be independently confirmed, how far above the official figure the total case numbers might be.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.
Social media users in Beijing and other cities said coworkers or classmates were ill and some businesses closed due to lack of staff.
The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other economies that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.

Beijing: A rash of COVID-19 cases in schools and businesses were reported by social media users Friday in areas across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules as it tries to reverse a deepening economic slump.
On Friday, the government reported 16,797 new cases, including 13,160 without symptoms.
That was down about one-fifth from the previous day and less than half of last weekï¿½s daily peak above 40,000.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.
Social media users in Beijing and other cities said co-workers or classmates were ill and some businesses closed due to a lack of staff.
But those donï¿½t include an unknown number of people who stay at home with COVID-19 symptoms and never report to the government.
The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other economies that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

China announces more easing of COVID restrictions following protests

But for some American companies with factories in China, it may be "too little, too late," as some said they are rethinking where they do business in Asia.

BEIJING -- A rash of COVID-19 cases in schools and businesses were reported Friday in areas across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules as it tries to reverse a deepening economic slump.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.

China announces more easing of COVID restrictions following protests

But for some American companies with factories in China, it may be "too little, too late," as some said they are rethinking where they do business in Asia.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict "zero COVID" policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict "zero COVID" policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.
Xiï¿½s government began to loosen controls Nov. 11 after promising to reduce their cost and disruption.
While official data showed a fall in new cases, they no longer cover large parts of the population after the government on Wednesday ended mandatory testing for many people.
On Friday, the government reported 16,797 new cases, including 13,160 without symptoms.
That was down about one-fifth from the previous day and less than half of last weekï¿½s daily peak above 40,000.
While official data showed a fall in new cases, they no longer cover large parts of the population after the government on Wednesday ended mandatory testing for many people.
The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.

The requirement for hundreds of millions of people to be tested as often as once a day in some areas over the past two years helped the government spot infections with no symptoms.

Nobodyï¿½s used to this yet.ï¿½

In other cities, social media users said coworkers or classmates were ill and some businesses had closed due to a lack of staff.
But those donï¿½t include an unknown number of people who stay at home with COVID-19 symptoms and never report to the government.
ï¿½Thereï¿½s very few people coming in because thereï¿½s so many cases,ï¿½ said Gang Xueping, a waitress in a Beijing restaurant.
ï¿½The countryï¿½s just opened up.
The first one or two months is definitely going to be serious.
ï¿½Thereï¿½s very few people coming in because thereï¿½s so many cases,ï¿½ said Gang Xueping, a waitress in a Beijing restaurant.
The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other countries that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.

The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other countries that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.
Restrictions probably must stay in place at least through mid-2023, public health experts and economists say.
China faces a daunting task after abruptly giving up on "zero-COVID," with infections set to surge and deaths predicted to top 2 million.

Unlike the whack-a-mole pattern of outbreaks that took place in the U.S. and Europe over months and years, China is likely to see a wave of infections engulf the country all at once in a population that until now has largely avoided exposure to the virus.
The result is Chinaï¿½s acceptance of COVID-19 will be like nothing the world has seen in the pandemic.
China wonï¿½t be the first to transition from zero-COVID, a process navigated with varying degrees of success by Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Australia.

Initial indications that China was exiting zero-COVID buoyed the nationï¿½s financial markets on expectations that the release of pent-up demand would spur consumer spending and drive an economic recovery.
Nevertheless, China has some advantages as it tries to fend off the worst-case scenario.

Yet China faces criticism that such plans have been left too late, with resources instead focused on keeping COVID-19 out ï¿½ similar to Hong Kong, which found its health care system overrun earlier in the year.

In this period, local government policies (are) also likely to vary as the singular goal of getting cases back to zero is gone and they are faced with a slew of new tasks.ï¿½

The fact that China is releasing the mitigation measures from zero-COVID without having fully established the methods to protect them as the pathogen spreads ï¿½ namely vaccines, health care facilities and easy-to-access therapeutics ï¿½ may make some backpedaling essential.
"China does not appear to be well prepared for a massive wave of COVID infections, and it may have to pay for its procrastination on embracing a ï¿½living with COVIDï¿½ approach.ï¿½
